title: Jesus at the Feast
shortSummary: John chapter 7 details Jesus’ interactions during the Feast of Tabernacles, highlighting the growing division among the people regarding His identity. Jesus teaches boldly in the temple, revealing His divine mission and promising the Holy Spirit to believers, while facing opposition from Jewish leaders.
timeline: c. AD 30 - Ministry of Jesus during the Feast of Tabernacles

keyCharacters.name: Jesus
keyCharacters.description: The Son of God who teaches openly at the Feast of Tabernacles, revealing His divine authority and mission.

keyCharacters.name: Jesus’ brethren
keyCharacters.description: Jesus’ brothers who initially do not believe in Him and urge Him to show Himself publicly.

keyCharacters.name: Pharisees and chief priests
keyCharacters.description: Religious leaders who oppose Jesus and seek to arrest Him.

keyCharacters.name: Nicodemus
keyCharacters.description: A Pharisee who cautiously defends Jesus by appealing to the law and justice.

definitions.definition: A Jewish festival commemorating Israel’s wilderness wanderings, involving dwelling in temporary shelters and celebrating God’s provision.
A physical sign of the covenant given to Abraham’s descendants, practiced even on the Sabbath as commanded by the law.
A metaphor used by Jesus to describe the Holy Spirit, who refreshes and sustains believers spiritually.
The exaltation of Jesus following His death and resurrection, enabling the giving of the Holy Spirit.

outline.heading: Jesus’ Initial Reluctance and Family’s Challenge
outline.description: Jesus remains in Galilee to avoid hostile Jews, despite His brothers urging Him to go publicly to Judea for the feast. He explains that His timing is controlled by God’s plan.

outline.heading: Public Reaction and Jesus’ Teaching in the Temple
outline.description: At the feast, people are divided about Jesus’ identity. Jesus teaches boldly, emphasizing that His message comes from God and challenges the people’s hypocrisy.

outline.heading: Jesus’ Identity and Authority Questioned
outline.description: Some question if Jesus is the Christ, noting confusion about His origins. Jesus speaks cryptically about His departure and the inability of His opponents to follow Him.

outline.heading: Jesus’ Invitation and Promise of the Spirit
outline.description: On the final day of the feast, Jesus invites those who thirst to come to Him and receive 'living water,' referring to the Holy Spirit promised to believers after His glorification.

outline.heading: Division Among the People and Religious Leaders’ Response
outline.description: The crowd is divided over Jesus’ identity; officers sent to arrest Him are impressed by His words. Nicodemus cautiously defends Jesus, but the Pharisees reject him and dismiss Jesus as a prophet from Galilee.

application: Trust in God’s timing for your life and ministry, following Jesus’ example of obedience rather than yielding to pressure.
Seek to know and do God’s will to discern true teaching, as Jesus taught that obedience reveals the source of doctrine.
Respond to Jesus’ invitation to receive the Holy Spirit, allowing Him to fill and empower your life with living water.
Stand firm in faith even when facing opposition or division, remembering that Jesus’ words have eternal authority.

keyVerses.text: Then Jesus said unto them, My time is not yet come: but your time is alway ready.
keyVerses.significance: Highlights Jesus’ submission to God’s perfect timing in His earthly ministry.

keyVerses.text: If any man will do his will, he shall know of the doctrine, whether it be of God, or whether I speak of myself.
keyVerses.significance: Emphasizes the importance of obedience in discerning the truth of Jesus’ teaching.

keyVerses.text: He that believeth on me, as the scripture hath said, out of his belly shall flow rivers of living water.
keyVerses.significance: Promises the indwelling Holy Spirit to all who believe in Jesus, providing spiritual life and refreshment.

keyVerses.text: The officers answered, Never man spake like this man.
keyVerses.significance: Acknowledges the unique authority and power of Jesus’ teaching, even recognized by His opponents.
